results.title: Paragon stereoviewer
results.brief_description: Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
results.description:
Three-dimensional images have been around for more than 180 years – they just weren’t called ‘3D’. Stereoscopic images are two separate pictures with slightly different perspectives. A stereoscopic viewer mimics how we see so that the two images converge into a single three-dimensional picture.

British inventor Charles Wheatstone discovered this process in 1838 and used a device as big as a table to make it work. Another British scientist, David Brewster, later simplified and shrank the viewer into a portable, hand-held device.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
description_for_label:
Three-dimensional images have been around for more than 180 years – they just weren’t called ‘3D’. Stereoscopic images are two separate pictures with slightly different perspectives. A stereoscopic viewer mimics how we see so that the two images converge into a single three-dimensional picture.

British inventor Charles Wheatstone discovered this process in 1838 and used a device as big as a table to make it work. Another British scientist, David Brewster, later simplified and shrank the viewer into a portable, hand-held device.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.

results.title: Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) Magic Lantern Projector
results.brief_description:
The Pettibone Mfg. Co. (Cincinatti, Ohio) patented this striking magic lantern with revolving disc in 1888 for use primarily in fraternal society lodges.
The revolving disc that holds 10 small circular discs of glass with brightly coloured pictures gave this version its popular nickname of the “peacock”, because of the resemblance to a peacock that has fanned out its tail.
The black triangle piece holds the revolving disc and has a click to lock the frames to prevent them from moving when they are projected.

-Object does not have a flue
-Lens can be extended 1.8 cm
-Internal condenser lens is a later addition and does not fit well

Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) Magic Lantern Projector - Ebay purchase

Original listing: https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/352469927305
From listing:
This is one that has been sitting collecting dust for many years, an 1880s dated Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) magic lantern projector. It has the stenciled triangle with the 1888 date as well as “Paragon” on the front which both sides have wear but these are actually harder to find with the painted stenciled lettering on it. The reel is full but a couple of the slides are broken but still for display purposes on a shelf looks alright. The body is the blued steel look which depending on the lighting either shows the blue look or more towards black if the lighting is bad. The front lens does extend with the turn knob and also retracts. The front lens & condensor lens are good just need a proper cleaning like the rest of this. The wood base does have some scratches which if someone were to use a stain pen you could probably fix those spots up pretty quick. Overall “G” good condition as seen with wear. The rails on this one are a brass color which the later models were just nickel plated. In back is no burner which it had been electrified so that old unit was thrown away.

The revolving disc that holds 10 small circular discs of glass with brightly coloured pictures gave this version its popular nickname of the “peacock”, because of the resemblance to a peacock that has fanned out its tail.

The black triangle piece holds the revolving disc and has a click to lock the frames to prevent them from moving when they are projected.

results.title: The Way of the Exploding Fist
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
‘The Way of the Exploding Fist’ was one of Beam Software’s best-selling games, and reached number one in Europe. It was one of the first ‘beat-‘em-up’ games for the home computer and the first multi-move beat em up. Jordan Mechner’s “Karateka”(1984) which came out just before “The Way of the Exploding Fist” was basically punch and kick.

The game offered an unprecedented sixteen karate moves, which allows for strategic game playing and complexity. Combinations of joystick directions (or keys on the keyboard) and the fire button (or SHIFT-key) make this game initially complicated to learn. However, once mastered, the controls are intuitive and become standard on single-button control systems. Designer and programmer Gregg Barnett practised all the movements as he developed it, mapping the combinations onto the joystick so that they felt fluid and natural.

The game allows for thumps, cracks and cries when you or your opponent is kicked effectively. Its sound design really bringing home the sense of the combat in contrast Neil Brennan‘s soundtrack offering an atmospheric sense of place. One of the most memorable features seems to be the intensive and high volume scream of ‘kai-ai ’ during the loading screen. made possible by Beam Softwares fast loader the Pav-Loada. The animation of the fighters is impressive, Beam’s artist Greg Holland cunningly dividing the body into two grids to support more complex animations. The quality of the graphics, including Japanese background imagery, adds to the overall essence of the game.

A review in “Crash” (issue 10, 1985, p12) says that “The Way of the Exploding Fist” ‘… is by far and away the best sports combat simulation available yet.’

[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/the-way-of-the-exploding-fist-c64/
Last accessed: 13/8/2020]

The Way of the Exploding Fist was one of Beam Software’s best-selling games, and reached number one in Europe. It was one of the first beat-em-up games for the home computer and the first multi-move beat-em-up. Jordan Mechner’s Karateka(1984), which came out just before The Way of the Exploding Fist, was basically punch and kick.

The game offered an unprecedented sixteen karate moves, which allows for strategic game playing and complexity. Combinations of joystick directions (or keys on the keyboard) and the fire button (or SHIFT-key) make this game initially complicated to learn. However, once mastered, the controls are intuitive and become standard on single-button control systems. Designer and programmer Gregg Barnett practised all the movements as he developed it, mapping the combinations onto the joystick so that they felt fluid and natural.

The game allows for thumps, cracks and cries when you or your opponent is kicked effectively. Its sound design really brings home the sense of the combat in contrast to Neil Brennan‘s soundtrack, which offers an atmospheric sense of place. One of the most memorable features seems to be the intensive and high volume scream of “:kai-ai”’ during the loading screen. made possible by Beam Software’s fast-loader, the Pav-Loada. The animation of the fighters is impressive, Beam’s artist Greg Holland cunningly dividing the body into two grids to support more complex animations. The quality of the graphics, including Japanese background imagery, adds to the overall essence of the game.

A review in Crash (issue 10, 1985, p12) says that The Way of the Exploding Fist “is by far and away the best sports combat simulation available yet.’

[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/the-way-of-the-exploding-fist-c64/

Last accessed: 13/8/2020]

Our version of the game is playable on Commodore 64 and Commodore 128.

results.title: The Way of the Exploding Fist  for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
‘The Way of the Exploding Fist’ was one of Beam Software’s best-selling games, and reached number one in Europe. It was one of the first ‘beat-‘em-up’ games for the home computer and the first multi-move beat em up. Jordan Mechner’s “Karateka”(1984) which came out just before “The Way of the Exploding Fist” was basically punch and kick.

The game offered an unprecedented sixteen karate moves, which allows for strategic game playing and complexity. Combinations of joystick directions (or keys on the keyboard) and the fire button (or SHIFT-key) make this game initially complicated to learn. However, once mastered, the controls are intuitive and become standard on single-button control systems. Designer and programmer Gregg Barnett practised all the movements as he developed it, mapping the combinations onto the joystick so that they felt fluid and natural.

The game allows for thumps, cracks and cries when you or your opponent is kicked effectively. Its sound design really bringing home the sense of the combat in contrast Neil Brennan‘s soundtrack offering an atmospheric sense of place. One of the most memorable features seems to be the intensive and high volume scream of ‘kai-ai ’ during the loading screen. made possible by Beam Softwares fast loader the Pav-Loada. The animation of the fighters is impressive, Beam’s artist Greg Holland cunningly dividing the body into two grids to support more complex animations. The quality of the graphics, including Japanese background imagery, adds to the overall essence of the game.

A review in “Crash” (issue 10, 1985, p12) says that “The Way of the Exploding Fist” ‘… is by far and away the best sports combat simulation available yet.’

[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/the-way-of-the-exploding-fist-c64/
Last accessed: 13/8/2020]

results.title: Magnavox Odyssey console
results.material_description: Video game console functioning as a playable unit. Also includes original box with contents
results.brief_description: Modified Odyssey video game console with original packaging, original contents and two controllers
results.description:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

The Magnavox Odyssey was released in 1972. Players controlled two dots while the console controlled another that darted around the screen and could be returned like the ball in pong. Though the basic gameplay was the same, people could put graphic overlays over their TV to create different game experiences, like skiing and football.
description_for_label:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

The Magnavox Odyssey was released in 1972. Players controlled two dots while the console controlled another that darted around the screen and could be returned like the ball in pong. Though the basic gameplay was the same, people could put graphic overlays over their TV to create different game experiences, like skiing and football.

results.title: Bringing his spirit home
results.creator_credit: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dot Peters’ father was 39 when he joined World War II. He fought in the Middle East and was later captured in Java and sent to a Prisoner of War camp in Japan. He died there, leaving a grieving family wondering what he went through. Simultaneously, they witnessed the injustices inflicted on fellow Indigenous servicemen who had experienced equality overseas, only to find it stripped away on their return. This inspired Dot to dedicate the rest of her life to fighting for Indigenous rights, eventually collaborating with the Shrine of Remembrance to recognise the contribution made by Indigenous people during the war. This fight has helped her to bring her father’s spirit home, to bestow upon his memory a sense of belonging, recognition and honour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

He died there, leaving a grieving family wondering what he went through. Simultaneously, they witnessed the injustices inflicted on fellow Indigenous servicemen who had experienced equality overseas, only to find it stripped away on their return. This inspired Dot to dedicate the rest of her life to fighting for Indigenous rights, eventually collaborating with the Shrine of Remembrance to recognise the contribution made by Indigenous people during the war. This fight has helped her to bring her father’s spirit home, to bestow upon his memory a sense of belonging, recognition and honour.
description_for_label: Dot Peters’ father was 39 when he joined World War II. He fought in the Middle East and was later captured in Java and sent to a Prisoner of War camp in Japan. He died there, leaving a grieving family wondering what he went through. Simultaneously, they witnessed the injustices inflicted on fellow Indigenous servicemen who had experienced equality overseas, only to find it stripped away on their return. This inspired Dot to dedicate the rest of her life to fighting for Indigenous rights, eventually collaborating with the Shrine of Remembrance to recognise the contribution made by Indigenous people during the war. This fight has helped her to bring her father’s spirit home, to bestow upon his memory a sense of belonging, recognition and honour.

results.title: Motion pictures. 1st 20 years. Part 1: 1898-1903
results.brief_description:
A compilation of silent films from 1898-1903. Films restored from the Library of Congress paper prints.
Contents: Elopement on horseback (1898)—Strange adventure of N.Y. Drummer (1899)—Uncle Josh’s nightmare (1900)—Terrible Teddy, the grizzly king (1901)—Love by the light of the moon (1901)—Panarama of esplanade by night (1901)—Martyred presidents (1901)—Uncle Josh at the moving picture show (1902)—Fun in a bakery shop (1902)—Jack and the beanstalk (1902)— Life of an American fireman (1903)

results.title: British Mutoscope featuring Charlie Chaplin reel
results.brief_description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope.

constellations_primary.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_primary.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

results.description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
description_for_label: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
